Why are you drawing an animal that has been pictured or drawn a millions times?

What’s the point? 

This was a fair question from a recent follower.

The truth is I don’t know. I only know how it makes me feel when I create it. Even when I’m using a reference. 

I like to think the human connection is meaningful to each of us. As the world automates itself, I am more optimistic each of us will be drawn to things created by humans. 

What do you think?

(Like and follow for a surprise final reveal on this Giraffe!)

#giraffeart #giraffeartwork #wildlifedrawings #charcoalmasters #charcaolart

“What will people think?”

Creating and sharing my art after a 20 year break has been a roller coaster. There are plenty of moments I overthink what I should share. I ask myself “what will people think?”

I’m recommitted to continue to draw and share what I enjoy. 

Thank you for following my journey. I’m excited about what’s ahead.

#nevertoolatetostart #dadart #wildlofeart #giraffeart #charcoalmasters

“Into the storm”

My story has been “It’s never too late to start” but in the case of @carli.noelle.williams the story should be “it’s never too early” to get checked for cancer. 

@carli.noelle.williams was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 33. She is the mother of 3 kids including twin boys & married to @raleighw 

I was honored to take on this commission and see how much it meant to them. 🫶

Go follow them to see how this bison headed “into the storm“ symbolizes how they’ve handled the ups and downs of cancer. 

4ft x 5ft
Multi-media 

#breastcancerawareness #cancersucks #bisonart #bisonintothestorm

What hobbies did you leave behind in your childhood?

When can you start them again?

I made a goal to reconnect with my childhood hobby at age 41. 

I made small goals at first. I started small and evolved as it felt natural. 

This year has already exceeded my expectations in every way. 

It makes me wonder how many of us are out there waiting for that extra nudge to start up an childhood passion. 

Maybe it’s time! 

#comebackstronger #wildlifeart #charcoalmasters #dailysketch #drawingnatureanimals #40sisthenew30s

I had a lot of fun on this commission.

A few things we added as the drawing went on:

✅ have Santa hold a list 
✅ add family names to the list 

I can’t wait to see this one in its new home! 

#holidayart #charcoalsanta #petportraits #santaslist #charcoalmasters

When facing Artist block remember: 

“Some is better than none”

I started this account in June of this year with a commitment to sketch in my sketch book each day. When I was tired or lacked motivation I told myself “some is better than none”. 

I’d give myself a 5 or 10 minute timer. I knew if I could just START I could keep the momentum. 

So for anyone on the fence wanting to start SOMETHING again, my advice is:

Don’t set big goals with big outcomes. 

Set a goal to simply start. 

Tell yourself it’ll probably be ugly. 

Tell yourself you will burn the paper afterward so that nobody sees (or hears). 

But start. Do some. Some is better than none. 

#mondaymotivation #artistblock #writersblock #wildlifeart #dailysketch

Did you grow up without social media?

As a kid in the 80’s I found myself drawing endlessly by myself. 99% of my sketches were never shared beyond my own room or my own sketchbook. 

After high school I did what most 80’s/90’s kid artists do…I stopped drawing… I went to big kid school, got a big kid job, and started a family.

20 years later (this year) I finally followed through on making art a part of my life again. 

Small daily goals have now evolved into drawing and sharing more than I ever imagined. 

I can’t help but think of how many “creators” are out there just like me. Is that you?

I hope this reel serves as your sign to “come back”. 

Follow me so we can help each other stay motivated ❤️🙌🏻

#80skids #90skid #unretiredartist #charcoalart #wildlifeart #dailysketches #animalart #petportraits #giraffeart

Creating something “ugly” takes courage.

Creating something “ugly” means you’re trying. 

I hope you don’t avoid creating because you’re worried about it being “ugly”. 

Let it be ugly. 

Let it teach you. 

Embrace the suck and embrace the “Ugly”. 

You might find out there is no “Ugly” after all. (You can still throw it away tho 😉). 

PS- This may not fully apply to tattoo artists 😂 rip @sophiatattoo @kenzaitattoo_art 

#createuglyart #dailysketch #charcoalart #easytosayhardtodo

Save this reel if you’re getting back into creating! (Re-post!)

I’m starting a new graphite drawing and thought I would re-share some tools I use. 

Materials/tools for graphite pencils, erasers/highlighters for graphite or charcoal.

Erasers:
AFMAT Electric eraser (a must IMO)
TOMBOW Zero

White highlights use:
Conte d’ Paris 013 pastel white
White Gel Pen (I’ve used a few - gelly roll Sakura is pictured but I’d try a few depending on medium)

For DARK Shading: (why isn’t your pencil shading as dark as the Pro’s!?!?)

MARS LUMOGRAPH BLACK Pencils !!! Get’em.

#artisttoolsofthetrade #graphitedrawing #marslumographblack #afmaterasers #tomboweraser

“The time will go by either way”

Creating and sharing my art after a 20 year break has been a roller coaster.

If you think it’s too late, remind yourself the time will go by either way. 

Thank you for following my journey. I’m excited about what’s ahead.

#nevertoolatetostart #dadart #wildlifeart #giraffeart #charcoalmasters #80skid #charcoalart

“Can you draw a lion?” (Save this reel to see tools used below)

Every artist knows this is the #1 request besides pet portraits. 

In general I have avoided the big cats. Lots of fur and lots of nuance. 

Drawing without a graph and just free handing forces me to be a little more loose and free. I hope you like it! 

Let me know what I should do as next Saturdays “free hand” sketch! 

Tools and Charcoal Used 

Kneaded Eraser 
TOMBOW Zero Eraser 
AFMAT Electric Eraser 
Good ol’ hobby lobby compress charcoal powder 
Raven’s Powder premium charcoal powder
Rotten old wooden watercolor brush (looks like Royal Gold brand)
Strathmore Charcoal Paper 300 series 
Cheap kitchen sponge

Top 3 things I learned by starting an art account in 2023

1️⃣ Human Connection

Most of my followers are here because my personal story resonated with them or someone they know. It wasn’t the art alone. 

If you walked through a building with art hanging on the wall, would you stop and admire it the same way you would if you met the artist who drew it? Or saw them drawing it as you walked by? Sharing your story can be powerful. 

2️⃣ Dont hate the player hate the game! 

You are on Social Media. This is ONE way of MANY to promote your art. Don’t be upset if the rules of social media don’t line up with your personal style to gain traction. It’s more meaningful to accept the rules of the road if you are gonna drive on its roads. 

Imagine having the most delicious cookie shop in the world but refusing to market the shop beyond a sign on your door because you believe people should just walk into your shop, taste it, and then tell their friends on their own. Now imagine 10 more cookie shops lined up next to yours and being upset more people aren’t walking into your shop. 

Remember: Instagram is a FREE social media platform many of us only dreamt of as kids. Because it’s free you are competing with thousands of artists trying to do the same thing. YES it can be overwhelming but it can also be an amazing way to share your art. 

3️⃣ Learn from everyone

If I see a great reel, a unique art style, or creative approach I think will help me, I reach out.  I have found most people are willing to share insight. This was true even when I only had a few hundred followers. I’ve gotten better at art, social media, and telling my story by being willing to let go of my preconceived notions and trying out new things. 

I hope this helps. I’m glad you are here!

“Can you draw a 🦣 Mammoth?”

Send this to an Ice Age fan! 

For my new followers:

(Almost) Each week I ask YOU to vote on various subjects to draw (Check my stories on Monday’s)

I draw these in one sitting to keep me fresh and loose in between commissions. 

Today I drew a Mammoth. 

2 things I learned about mammoths:
1- Both male and female mammoths have tusks
2- the mammoth ear was smaller so it wouldn’t get too cold with all that surface area

Follow me to vote and see next weeks sketch (along with my other art!)

I think about this quote daily. 

In an odd way it helps me “abandon” projects earlier than desired and at other times helps me push through a little longer. 

The question is, what have you abandoned? Is it time to “come back” to your “unfinished” creation and add a little more detail? 

If you are reading this, it might be time for you to return to something you abandoned years ago 👀

Let me know your thoughts on this quote below ⬇️

#nevertoolate #charcoalwildlife #charcoalart #johnnyclarkart

I am really enjoying all things black and white right now. 

I’m asked all the time “why don’t you try color?” “Are your skills limited to black and white?”

My answer?

“Yes Henry. My skills are limited.” 😂

I enjoy working in black and white right now. I have tons I wanna master with charcoal, graphite, and pen.

Most of us have limited time to be creative. 

Don’t waste your precious time learning something you are feeling pressured to master. 

Oil artists don’t have to master acrylic. Romance writers don’t have to master sci-fi (but they can if they want!). 

Do it because you are curious. Do it because you know it’s hard and deep down it would mean a lot for you to improve. 

Do NOT do it because Aunt Nancy thinks real artists “use color” or “paint with xxx medium”. 

Happy Creating! 

#create #yolo #charcoalartist
